mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mathcal{S}(e_{i}\otimes e_{j})=e_{j}\otimes e_{i}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒮</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⊗</mo><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>⊗</mo><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mathcal{T}=\begin{pmatrix}0&1\\
1&0\end{pmatrix}\otimes\begin{pmatrix}0&1\\
1&0\end{pmatrix}\cdot\mathcal{S},\qquad\mathcal{T}(e_{i}\otimes e_{j})=e_{j+1}%
\otimes e_{i+1}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒯</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⊗</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒮</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="22.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒯</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⊗</mo><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⊗</mo><msub><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: In particular, Hietarinta discovered the following solution to the \emph{four}-simplex equation~\cite[Subsection~6.21]{hietarinta}:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="R_{i_{1}\dots i_{n}}^{j_{1}\dots j_{n}}=\delta_{A_{1}^{\alpha}i_{\alpha}+B_{1}%
}^{\,j_{1}}\dots\delta_{A_{n}^{\alpha}i_{\alpha}+B_{n}}^{\,j_{n}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>R</mi><mrow><msub><mi>i</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>j</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>j</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mn>1</mn><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>α</mi></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><msub><mpadded lspace="1.7pt" width="+1.7pt"><mi>j</mi></mpadded><mn>1</mn></msub></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>i</mi><mi>α</mi></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mpadded lspace="1.7pt" width="+1.7pt"><mi>j</mi></mpadded><mi>n</mi></msub></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: It is well-known that if there is a solution to $n$-simplex equation then a solution to $(n-1)$-simplex equation can be obtained by taking a \emph{partial trace} in one pair of indices. For instance, if $\tilde{\mathcal R}_{i_1i_2i_3i_4}^{j_1j_2j_3j_4}$ enjoys the four-simplex equation, then

For instance, if $\tilde{\mathcal R}_{i_1i_2i_3i_4}^{j_1j_2j_3j_4}$ enjoys the four-simplex equation, then

prevtext: is a solution to tetrahedron. Partial trace of~\eqref{R4} in the fourth pair of indices gives the sum

nexttext:
Note that operator~$\mathcal S$ satisfies by itself the tetrahedron equation (and can be obtained by central reflection from the second solution in~\cite[Subsection~5.4]{hietarinta}).

Operator~\eqref{S+T} is highly degenerate: of rank~$4$, while acting in an eight-dimen\-sional space. It can still be already interesting, as explained in our Subsection~\ref{ss:non-inv}. Remarkably, it can also be generalized, according to formula~\eqref{S+aT} below, while still obeying the (now non-constant) tetrahedron equation.



\section{Linear combinations of permutation-type solutions to the tetrahedron equation, and a 16-vertex model in three dimensions}\label{s:lcp}

We consider the following non-constant tetrahedron equation:
prevtext: of two permutation-type operators, corresponding to the following two respective matrices $[A|B]$:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="[A|B]_{\mathcal{S}}=\left[\begin{array}[]{ccc|c}1&1&1&0\\

0&1&0&0\end{array}\right],\qquad[A|B]_{\mathcal{T}}=\left[\begin{array}[]{ccc|%
c}1&1&1&1\\
0&0&1&1\\

Note that operator~$\mathcal S$ satisfies by itself the tetrahedron equation (and can be obtained by central reflection from the second solution in~\cite[Subsection~5.4]{hietarinta}).

Operator~\eqref{S+T} is highly degenerate: of rank~$4$, while acting in an eight-dimen\-sional space. It can still be already interesting, as explained in our Subsection~\ref{ss:non-inv}. Remarkably, it can also be generalized, according to formula~\eqref{S+aT} below, while still obeying the (now non-constant) tetrahedron equation.

We consider the following non-constant tetrahedron equation:
